Speaker.P: At the outset I should like to compliment Senator Ryan very sincerely not just on the detailed research he and those who worked with him put into this Bill but also on the way in which he has pursued its implementation and its treatment here today. It is quite clear from the manner in which Senator Brendan Ryan has been able to mobilise the practical experience and commitment of so many people not just in the Simon Community but also in voluntary housing associations, that he has brought to bear the resources of a very large number of people whose commitment and expertise are not to be doubted.

We have studied this Bill in considerable detail and with great attention. It is fair to say — and I say it politically — that the work Senator Ryan and his colleagues have done has enabled the Department of the Environment, whose resources are infinitely greater than those of the voluntary people to whom Senator Ryan has referred, to build extensively on the statistics and the research embodied in Senator Ryan's speech.

MainHeading.P: I was not in the House when the Order of Business was agreed. I had a meeting with my own party colleagues and in addition to detailed and long discussions with Labour Party Senators I had discussions with our friends, the Fine Gael Party with whom we share Government, and following the representations made it was agreed that the reasoned amendment would not be moved. I am pleased that that decision was taken by the Senators on the Government side.

Influence, shall we say, was mobilised in the form of telegrams and telexes from a wide range of people. I and the Labour Party and our colleagues in Fine Gael, and I believe many other people in the Seanad, agree with the principle and the objectives of this Bill. The historical outline presented here today reflects a shame on all of us as legislators, and we should act quickly to remove it. I intend to do so for as long as I have the responsibility in the Department. My responsibility is tempered by two existing realities with which the practical people of the Simon Community frequently have to grapple. One: do we have the resources to deal with the problem? Two: is our solution effective and practicable? One real difficulty in a society that refuses to pay tax in effect, and yet wants everything today, is the cost of providing any kind of service.

Our local authority housing programme this year will cost £208 million. That is for the construction of new houses. In addition to that, the subsidy which we provide for the differential rent sector will cost another £126 million. We have 30,000 people on our local authority housing list, and we are building approximately 6,000 dwellings per year. A major cost in the provision of such local authority houses is the cost of building land, a matter about which I have spoken before. The cost of building land, depending upon its location and depending upon its zoning, can be extremely expensive. I was particularly heartened, and indeed caused to be somewhat optimistic, when I got the telex addressed to me from the Justice Commission of the Conference of Major Religious Superiors in Ireland and I will quote the text:
We strongly recommend you support the second reading of the Housing (Homeless Persons) Bill, 1982, in Seanad Éireann tomorrow, Wednesday.

It was signed by Fr. Joseph Dargan, Chairman, Provincial, Jesuits, Sister Jordana Roche, General, Dominicans, Sister Lucy Troy, General, Presentation Sisters, Fr. John O'Donnell, Provincial, Redemptorists, Fr. William McGonigle, Provincial, Oblates, Sister Nellie Curtin, Provincial, Little Sisters of the Assumption, Sister Pauline Lawlor, Provincial, Daughters of Charity, Sister Stanislaus Kennedy, Provincial, Irish Sisters of Charity, Fr. Michael Mornagh, Augustinian, Fr. Michael Kane, Holy Ghost Fathers.

I have taken the opportunity to read their names into the record and more particularly the orders they represent, with the specific aspiration that the enormous land holdings they possess as religious orders will, somehow or other, not be given to the local authorities, but be made available to the local authorities at their existing use value, and not at the development value which would prevail because of speculative planning permissions many of them have obtained if they were to sell such lands on the open market. I am optimistic that, in view of their concern and the way in which Senator Ryan has so ably mobilised them, we will get the kind of response which is evident in this telex.

However, history would temper my optimism. When Councillor Dermot O'Rourke was vice-chairman of the Dublin Housing Committee of the Corporation in 1967, a letter to the religious orders from that committee did not meet with the same prompt attention this telex has manifested here today. I think it is true to say — and I am subject to correction — that when the present Catholic Archbishop of the Dublin diocese was consecrated, one of the progressive initiatives that he took was to give Merrion Square back to Dublin City, for which the citizens will be eternally grateful. He also responded to the housing problem by setting up the Bethlehem Foundation, a voluntary housing association, an organisation which was able to tap the resources of a very committed person who had worked in shelter agencies in London, Mr. Bill Darman, with the idea of utilising in the Dublin area much of the land owned by the religious orders whose names are represented on this telex today.

To my knowledge there is only one successful scheme that started nearly ten years ago from that progressive initiative, the Bethlehem Foundation. Significantly it was the bishop himself who donated the land. I stand open to correction but, with the exception of one other religious group and one religious order in the north west part of Dublin city, no other land bank of any consequence, or indeed at all, has been made available. I make that point at some length to demonstrate to people who have practical experience, as Senator Ryan has said, the constraints and the difficulties that exist in making a reality out of the principles and the objectives of this Bill.

I am the first to admit that Senator Ryan, by bringing this Bill before the House, has served to concentrate our minds on an important social issue and to stimulate an overdue debate on the problem of homelessness. I am grateful to him for that. I have no argument with him about the existence of a problem of homelessness and I have the fullest sympathy with the motivation underlying his Bill. I readily accept that there is a problem. I would like to emphasise at the outset, however, that the question at issue then is not whether a problem exists but how we can best set about tackling it. This is where I find myself differing, to some extent, from him.

I hope that I can satisfy him and other Senators that the passing of this Bill into law now would not solve the problem of homelessness but would rather create more problems than it would resolve by injecting confusion into our housing system, and in particular by artificially and arbitrarily dividing the housing problem in a way that would not reflect the relative patterns of need of the many families and individuals who are in urgent need of housing. We have a duty to these people — and I as Minister have no option but to accept this — to ensure that the housing that can be provided from the resources available is allocated fairly on the basis of objective and defensible criteria.

Coming into the Seanad today and being unable to accept on behalf of the Government such an obviously well intentioned and socially concerned measure is not something that I relish. I am conscious of the risk that the Government's stance could be falsely portrayed as being unsympathetic to or unconcerned about the plight of the homeless. I personally am profoundly concerned about this serious problem, but I want to be sure that whatever action is taken is well defined and likely to prove successful without imposing penalties and hardship on persons and families who otherwise deserve to be treated as a housing priority.

Regrettably, having examined the Bill and its implications in depth, I have to say that in its present form it would not contribute to the achievement of the ideals to which the Senator and I — and indeed the Tánaiste and the Government as a whole — are fully committed. It would, on the contrary, tend to frustrate those ideals by upsetting traditional and well-established policies of ensuring that local authority housing is allocated to those whose need is most acute, in accordance with recognised criteria.

I myself have been clearly conscious for some considerable time of the extent and acute nature of the problem of homelessness, particularly in the Dublin area where I am most familiar with the human tragedy and personal hardship to which it gives rise. I am familiar with the pamphlet entitled “The Case for a Homeless Person's Act” which has been published by the Simon Community — an organisation that, I know, is doing tremendous work on behalf of the homeless and that is eminently qualified to speak about the problems of homelessness. Anyone with a social conscience could not fail to be impressed by this document. The Society of St. Vincent de Paul, in their document “Towards a National Social Policy” have also called for action in this area. Many other voluntary bodies and individuals concerned with the less privileged have likewise added their voices to the call for action. Certainly, anyone who has nowhere to live is lacking one of the two most basic necessities of life — food and shelter — and merits priority consideration in terms of the social services provided by the State. Some of those whom this Bill is designed to help have, by any standards, an unacceptable existence and are condemned to a way of life which any civilised society should be striving to ameliorate.

It is obvious, therefore, that there is a lot of common ground between Senator Ryan and myself. The difference between us concerns methods, not objectives, and I personally cannot see any real grounds for confrontation. It is a matter of much regret to me that certain developments on the Bill may have created a contrary impression. I feel sure there is scope for reconciling our approaches in a mutually acceptable way since, as I have said, essentially we are striving to accomplish the same objective.

My approach is one of framing a comprehensive and effective policy to alleviate the plight of homeless people and to underpin that policy by improved and appropriate statutory provisions. For reasons that I shall go into in more detail later, the Bill before the House does not add up to what is required, in our view. It is so fundamentally different in its approach from the existing legislation on the provision and letting of housing by housing authorities that I am fully satisfied that both pieces of legislation could not exist comfortably side by side on the Statute Book without giving rise to severe practical and legal difficulties. Legislation to help deal with the problem of homelessness — which is just a part, albeit a very important part, of the overall housing problem — will have to be compatible with housing legislation generally forming a properly integrated housing code; otherwise, the effective operation of our housing programme will, I believe, be disrupted.

The development of better legislation in this area must be looked at from a number of viewpoints. These include the existing other special needs for housing and the difficulties which have arisen in regard to the letting of houses following a recent Supreme Court decision in the Buncrana case which has the effect of precluding a housing authority from letting a house to a person resident or domiciled in the functional area of another authority. Because of the particular urgency of overcoming the difficulties arising from the Buncrana judgment, the Government intend as a first step to bring forward within the next few weeks a very short piece of amending legislation solely to get over these particular difficulties. Concurrently my Department are also engaged in an urgent examination of Part III of the Housing Act, 1966, with a view to bringing forward more satisfactory provisions. I am confident that we will be able to complete this examination within a short period to enable a proper statutory framework for the administration of local authority housing — including meeting the needs of the homeless — to be formulated and brought forward for consideration by both Houses.

In considering the best approach, we must start by looking at the existing statutory powers and responsibilities of the local housing authorities and the regional health boards. Although most Senators will be generally familiar with the responsibilities of local authorities and health boards in relation to the provision of accommodation, in order to keep the debate in perspective, I think it would be helpful for me to spell these out briefly.

Housing authorities have a statutory duty under the Housing Act, 1966 — which in itself is a major piece of legislation and incorporated all of the previous body of housing legislation enacted since independence in 1921 and previous to it — to survey the housing conditions in their functional areas at least once in every five years to ascertain the extent of unfit and overcrowded housing and to assess the adequacy of the supply and condition of the housing as well as the future demand for housing in their areas. They are then to prepare and adopt a building programme setting out the works which they propose to undertake having regard to the housing needs of their area. The Act also empowers the authorities to provide dwellings and other related facilities or amenities.

The authorities are further required to make a scheme of letting priorities which must be approved by the Minister for the Environment and in accordance with which their houses are to be let. In making a scheme they must have regard to certain statutory primary objectives, namely, the elimination of unfit housing and overcrowding and the provision of accommodation for persons in need of it who are unable to provide it from their own resources. It is open to housing authorities either to obtain a report from a medical officer of health of the appropriate board in all cases, or only in cases where priority is claimed on medical grounds, but where such a report is obtained regard must be had to it.

While housing authorities are required to adopt a scheme of letting priorities and to make lettings according to the scheme there is no obligation on them to have formal waiting lists of persons who have applied for housing, though in practice the majority of authorities operate some type of list. These lists are reviewed periodically to include recently approved applicants and to take account of changed circumstances of those already listed. At present there are about 30,000 approved applicants throughout the country waiting to be housed.

There are, however, two special categories of persons to whom preference is given outside of the scheme of letting priorities. These are the elderly and the disabled; neither would in the normal course have high priority vis-à-vis families, and they are enabled to be housed sooner than would otherwise be the case by the provision of special purpose-built houses. Overall, about 10 per cent of the annual local authority housing output is comprised of units suitable for elderly or disabled persons.

Schemes of letting priorities can provide for permanent or temporary housing on an emergency basis where, say, a household becomes homeless as a result of fire, flood, house collapse or eviction through no fault of their own. Housing authorities may, from time to time, have a small reserve of untenanted houses which can be used in cases of emergency, but their capacity to respond in this way is necessarily limited. This is because of the difficulty of maintaining a significant reserve of dwellings when the ordinary demand for housing is so strong, the financial constraints which limit the construction programme, and the arrangements for priorities, which I have already outlined, under which these houses are let. These arrangements are essential if we are to have a just and rational system of allocating houses and if the public at large are to have confidence in the policies and practices of local authorities in this highly sensitive area. Because of the increasing pressure on those housing lists there are many sections of the public in different local authority areas who are rapidly losing confidence in the objectivity and fairness of their allocation system. As a consequence, any measure which in our view would tend to aggravate that loss of confidence would have a very counter-productive effect from everybody's point of view.

Except in emergency situations, therefore, homeless persons who are not elderly or disabled, to be eligible for permanent local authority accommodation, must apply for housing, be accepted as being in need of accommodation, and qualify for housing on the basis of the order of priority laid down in the local authority's scheme or letting priorities.

Essentially, the local authorities must focus their efforts primarily on families or individuals whose needs are for permanent housing rather than temporary accommodation and who are capable of holding independent tenancies. I will return and stress what we mean by that and the implications of it for the housing stock in general and for a housing authority. In fairness, it should be acknowledged that local authorities have catered over the years for many families who have been rendered homeless for one reason or another. In fact, it is fair to say that any family — by this I mean a parent or parents and one or more children — who find themselves genuinely homeless are normally given accommodation quickly by the housing authority.

In this context, it is worth recording that Dublin Corporation — the largest housing authority in the State — in the first six months of this year housed 54 families, 97 one-parent families, 35 couples and 30 single persons, mostly senior citizens, all of whom were classified as homeless. The corporation have re-let to single people a number of small flats in various locations originally intended for the elderly but which subsequently became unsuitable for this purpose.

Also from time to time the corporation have made lettings to psychiatric hospitals and other organisations for use as transitional accommodation between institutional and ordinary accommodation. In that regard, the political decision of Dublin Corporation's Housing Committee to respond in 1975-76 to such a request proved to be extremely emotive and difficult, and in my memory ranged over at least four separate meetings. We finally had to request the chief psychiatrist, Dr. Ivor Browne, to explain to the more cautions, conservative, reactionary, frightened, or whatever adjective you want to use, members of that housing authority just what was intended by the health board and the kind of prospective tenants that would share those dwellings. This has proved to be an extremely difficult task for local housing authorities because of fears which are in many cases unnecessarily stirred up or provoked. The struggle is going on in relation to some hostel accommodation in this city at the present moment.

In addition, the corporation are examining, in consultation with the voluntary organisations, how they can provide more housing for single persons. The housing package one of the Tánaiste's predecessors launched in the Spring of 1981 does provide for a range of measures which, hopefully, would enable voluntary organisations to try and provide more housing for single persons. I recognise that there are considerable difficulties in the implementation and the practical operation of that particular package.

I should point out here that there is a vast difference between giving housing authorities general responsibility for the provision of housing for any category, be they homeless or others, and imposing — as this Bill will do — a statutory duty on housing authorities to house all persons in a particular category, thus conferring on them a superior right to housing. I know from political experience that the degree of abuse to which Senator Ryan referred, and which he minimised, is not a degree that some people in Dublin city would agree with. I am aware of one particular housing estate, known locally as “Little Lourdes” because the vast majority of people housed there were housed on the basis of medical priority, and all of them, it appeared to the people who were not housed, had the benefit of miraculous cures after they were housed. In the eyes of the people who did not get housed there was a belief that that particular fast track of overall priority to local authority housing had been abused: I stress the word “belief” rather than any factual evidence that would underpin that. That is something I know from my own practical knowledge of Dublin city and is another indication of how careful we must be in structuring any measures to deal with what is a very difficult problem.

Now to turn to the role of the health boards. Section 54 of the Health Act, 1953, imposes a qualified duty on health boards to provide institutional assistance for any person who is unable to provide shelter and maintenance for himself or his dependants. In practice, there is quite an amount of variation in the type of accommodation provided directly or subvented by health boards. Every health board has some provision for sheltering homeless people. In those areas where boards do not make use of their own institutions they grant-aid voluntary and religious bodies who provide hostels or other facilities or, alternatively, they place and pay for homeless people in rented accommodation such as flats, houses, bed-and-breakfast, mobile homes and caravans. Senator Ryan's speech clearly outlined the different ways local authorities and health boards respond in that way.

Health boards regard their responsibility as extending only to providing temporary accommodation, that is shelter, for homeless people. They are not responsible for providing permanent accommodation for individuals who are considered houseable. This is the responsibility of local authorities.

While the respective responsibilities of the health boards and the housing authorities may, from what I have said, seem to be reasonably clearly defined, I would not attempt to deny that, in practice, there has been great confusion about the extent of responsibility in individual cases and that there have been differing interpretations of the provisions of the Health Act by local authorities and health boards. The case for the present Bill is based, to a large extent, on this perceived ambiguity of responsibility for the provision of accommodation for homeless persons. I support that Bill in so far as it highlights that case. I would accept that there is a need for clear, sharp guidelines as to the division of responsibility between health boards and housing authorities and for a better understanding by these bodies of their respective roles.

I would accept also that there are significant differences of approach to the problem of homelessness between the various local authorities. It is acknowledged by the voluntary organisations that some authorities take a very sympathetic view of cases of homelessness brought to their attention and that they have succeeded in resolving many bad cases. On the other hand, it is contended that other authorities take a less helpful view of similar type cases. Again we got specific documented evidence of that in the speech from Senator Ryan here today. In these circumstances, I also accept that there is a need for a greater consistency of approach as between local authorities in responding to cases of homelessness. This inconsistency may well be due to differing interpretations regarding the respective responsibilities of the health boards and the housing authorities, and if these roles were satisfactorily delineated I think it would also go a long way towards achieving the uniformity in the response of local authorities that is desired. Of course, differing local housing circumstances may also be a contributing factor to the varying responses of local authorities.

Earlier this year the Minister for Health set up an ad hoc committee, comprising representatives of that Department, the Department of Social Welfare, my own Department, the health boards and the local authorities, to investigate and make recommendations on these questions. In their examination of the issues involved this committee have had the benefit of submissions from the non-statutory agencies or bodies, including the Simon Community, who are most intimately concerned with the problem of homelessness. Considering that the committee are representative of all the statutory bodies involved in dealing with the problem and who have first hand practical experience of trying to administer it as distinct from operating it on behalf of clients, I am confident that they will be in a position to take a fairly fundamental look at these important aspects of the homelessness problem and that they will come up with recommendations that will be clearcut, practical and, hopefully, effectual. I am hopeful that the committee's recommendations will be available in a matter of weeks. We should then be in a position to issue clear guidelines to health boards and housing authorities about the division of responsibilities and to set about framing an effective policy for the homeless. It seems likely, too, that the committee's recommendations could have a worthwhile bearing on the direction of the legislative measures that may be needed.

Incidentally, the Simon Community, in a letter of 28 February to the ad hoc committee, are on record as saying that if the question of the division of responsibility between the health boards and the housing authorities can be resolved without recourse to legislation, that would be entirely acceptable to them.

At this stage it is necessary that I should take the Bill before the House and spell out what we believe are the shortcomings and some of the reasons why it could not be acceptable in its present form. We considered in great detail whether it could be possible to make the Bill acceptable by amendment of its provisions. The conclusion had to be that such a course would not be feasible. It would have been necessary to alter fundamentally the nature of the measure by a series of major changes. Even if it was possible to devise coherent amendments, the end result would have been a piece of legislation which, to put it crudely, would be a patched up job. I believe the correct course to be the one I have already outlined — that the Government should bring forward their own proposals framed after reasoned and mature consideration of all the possibilities and implications. In giving that commitment to the House it is quite clear that the urgency that will underpin the work of the Government and the legislation we will draft, will undoubtedly owe its authorship to the pioneering work Senator Brendan Ryan and his colleagues have undertaken. Therefore I would see the legislation, which will be enacted during this session by both Houses, as being linked with the Bill that is before the House now and the measures which we will bring forward as a matter of urgency.

Senator Ryan has attached some importance to three aspects of the Bill — its definition of a homeless person, the responsibility of local authorities and their duty to house homeless persons. I shall now deal in some detail with these particular facets of the Bill. The term “the homeless” has different meanings for different people. For instance, there is quite clearly a vast difference between the type of person referred to in the Simon Community's document and the scope of the definition of “homelessness” contained in the Bill now before the House. The Simon document really deals with what is perhaps the most acute form of homelessness — men, women or even children on their own who have ceased to associate with family or relatives, who have no accommodation and who sleep rough or in hostels, night shelters or who are forced to reside in institutions. Some of them would have medical or psychological problems.

It is not clear to many of the social workers involved if those problems are as a result of being homeless or whether those problems prevent them from being properly housed. Some are on the margins of society or have opted out of society altogether. The extent of the deprivation and misery which some of these people may suffer is extreme and it has been clearly put on the record of this House today.

But the definition of homelessness in the Bill is much broader. As I read it, many families who are on local authority waiting lists would come within the terms of this Bill if enacted in its present form. For example, a family that is “vulnerable” as a result of living in unfit accommodation or in unhealthy or overcrowded conditions could well be covered. Similarly, many travelling families, families who are involuntarily sharing accommodation, men who are barred from their houses by the courts, would appear to come within the scope of this Bill. Even more of a problem, however, in putting this Bill into practice would be the concept of “threatened homelessness” as defined in the Bill. Under section 4 (2) a person or family would, in effect, have to be treated as homeless if it is likely that within 28 days he will become homeless and in need of accommodation. This could well include a family where the breadwinner becomes unemployed and cannot meet mortgage repayments.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Ryan Mr. B. Ryan
Speaker.P: Come on.

In reading the fine print of legislation as drafted, the worst possible outcome has to be theoretically considered. Senator Ryan's record as a legislator, in which he has paid great attention to such detail in other measures, would indicate that he shares very clearly that concern for legislative excellence which, no doubt, since he applies it to other measures in this House, he would like to apply to his own. For that reason, we have to look at the extreme possibilities — and I accept in some cases they are extreme possibilities — that could happen. They are capable of being amended and provided for, but in terms of legislation one must have, and should have, regard for them. The fact that the definition of “homelessness” in the Bill is so wide would mean that many of the cases which would come within the scope of the Bill are already being catered for, in accordance with the priorities laid down, among the 8,000 or so lettings made each year by housing authorities.

MainHeading.P: The Bill therefore would impose a statutory duty on housing authorities to provide permanent accommodation for very broadly and loosely defined categories of persons. As I have indicated, many of those who are already on local authority waiting lists would certainly come within the categories covered by this Bill. The imposition of a specific duty on these authorities to house all those who would come within the scope of the Bill would put local authorities in an impossible position. It would, for example, disrupt the long established practice of allocating houses on the basis of relative need and having regard to the primary objectives laid down in section 60 of the Housing Act, 1966. In effect, it would create two different routes to rehousing — one through the existing scheme of letting priorities and the other through being homeless or threatened with homelessness. Because of the duty being imposed, the Bill would, de facto, give preference to persons whose needs might not by any means be the most acute. Clearly, there would be an incentive for ordinary applicants to have themselves classified as homeless, or so threatened, in order to gain priority.

Regrettably I and many Senators in this House — I can temporarily include myself as a Senator having been here on two occasions although I was not very anxious to stay, which is no disrespect to Senators — are also members of local authorities and as such deal with people who are attempting to be housed by the local authority. We know very well the limits and the stratagems to which many people will go to get what they desperately need, and which the public representative will encourage and try and help them to get, that is, a house. The kind of abuse, or potential abuse, that Senator Ryan suggests may not happen, and which probably would not happen in relation to some of the clients who are catered for by the existing voluntary agents who deal with the conventional homeless people, if you want to put it that way, would, in my considered view as a working politician at local level, undoubtedly happen unless the loopholes as perceived by us in this legislation are closed. I invite Senators who contribute to this legislation and who have local authority experience and experience working as constituency representatives to comment on how some of these provisions might operate if applied to the general category of people looking for housing, not to the conventional people who are classified as homeless and not to the 3,000 estimated by Simon as being the extent of the number of people requiring to be housed, excluding people known as the travellers.

To enact this legislation in its present form would be bordering on irresponsible because it would impose a duty on local authorities that could not be discharged within the resources likely to be available to them. To do so would bring the law into disrepute, probably lead to expensive litigation seeking to secure the performance by local authorities of the duty imposed on them, and be most unfair to families who have been deservedly placed on approved waiting lists.

I am aware that it is frequently claimed by those working with the homeless that many of their psychological and social problems stem from their lack of roots in society which a home gives them. I would not dispute that many can successfully make the transition from a state of being homeless to settling in permanent accommodation, if they are adequately prepared and given minimal support. However, there are certainly some among the homeless — perhaps some of the most pathetic cases — whose problems cannot be solved by the provision of permanent housing. Some of these people do not want to settle in permanent accommodation; others would not be able to cope with an independent tenancy; many need special medical or other care and support. In summary, housing may not be their primary need, and for these this Bill would do little to solve the real underlying problems.

I would also be worried that, once a duty to house the homeless is imposed on local authorities it would be very difficult to prevent abuses such as intentional homelessness. The Bill, as currently drafted, makes no attempt to deal with abuses of this nature, but once such an all-embracing duty is imposed it would be difficult, if not impossible, effectively to circumscribe it in such a way as to prevent abuses and preserve confidence in the fairness of the housing allocations.

As I said earlier, many travelling people would come within the meaning of homeless in this Bill and I think it would not be out of place here to refer to the problems of the travelling people in the context of this Bill. As Senators will be aware, the Review Body on Travelling People, who presented their report last May, dealt at length with the need to provide permanent accommodation for travellers who desire to settle. The review body were critical of the record of some housing authorities in this area but did not consider that a fundamental recasting of housing legislation was necessary. Furthermore, the review body came down against the idea of imposing a statutory responsibility for the provision of accommodation on a central authority.

Having considered this report, the Government decided to establish a Government Review Body, of which I am Chairperson, to ensure that the recommendations in the report are given urgent consideration by the relevant Departments and public authorities and to identify and implement those recommendations which are feasible in the current financial situation. This Government Review Body are now in the process of developing further proposals for submission to the Government. I do not envisage a recommendation that the travelling people — deserving as they are — be given a statutory right to housing which would give them a priority over other equally deprived members of the community.

For as long as we have a growing population — especially when allied to high unemployment — the allocation of local authority dwellings is inevitably going to be a matter of determining priorities in accordance with relative need. In this context the imposition of a statutory duty on local authorities in respect of one loosely defined category of persons, the acuteness of whose need for housing may vary widely from case to case, would clearly be invidious and would, understandably, be widely resented.

Because it is utterly impossible to predict how many persons or families would be admitted under the terms of this Bill as currently drafted, it would not be possible to attempt to estimate the cost of its implementation — either in terms of the capital cost of providing housing or of the consequent recurring expenditure by way of subsidy, administration and maintenance. The Simon Community have given a figure of perhaps 3,000 homeless people in Ireland but many more than this would come within the scope of this Bill. Elderly persons' dwellings are currently costing about £20,000 each to construct so to provide 3,000 units of permanent residential accommodation, one is talking about £60 million which, in terms of total provision of £208 million for public housing this year, is a formidable sum. Furthermore, the Bill would have other financial implications for housing authorities arising from the need for extra personnel, legal expenses and the cost of providing temporary accommodation.

Senator Ryan has implied that the Bill corresponds to the UK. Housing (Homeless Persons) Act, 1977 which, incidentally, does not apply in Northern Ireland. I must make it clear that there are fundamental differences between the British Act and the Bill before the House. It is true that the 1977 Act imposes a duty on housing authorities to provide accommodation for the homeless but it applies to a much less extensive category of persons and in our view did not in practice have anything like the kind of implications for public housing there that this Bill would have here. In fact during the Commons debate and in the relevant Department of the Environment circular, it was made clear that there could be no overall increase in public expenditure as a result of the Act.

The duty to house people imposed by the British Act extends only to those who have a priority need for accommodation because of very special reasons such as dependent children, pregnancies, emergency or old age, disability, mental illness and so on. Generally speaking, present practice in this country secures priority treatment for those covered by the British Act and the application of that Act here would make no appreciable difference and little at all to the single homeless. On the other hand, any concept of priority is entirely missing from the Bill before the House — the duty to house homeless people is unqualified in its application — single homeless people, homeless couples without children would have a right superior to families and so on who though not homeless could have a more acute need for rehousing because of overcrowding, unfitness, dangerous or unhealthy existing accommodation.

Again, the British Act contains provisions to safeguard against intentional homelessness, a feature missing from the Bill. Where individual provisions correspond to those in the British Act, it needs to be remembered that their practical operation is very much different given the restricted duty imposed on local authorities in Britain compared with the much widespread duty the Bill would place on our local authorities.

I trust that I have demonstrated my concern and that of the Government to ensure that early steps are taken to improve the lot of the homeless. However, in the light of its many shortcomings I do not see that this Bill in its present form would provide a solution to the problems. Indeed, in many respects the Bill would give rise to other difficulties not least its undermining of established priorities in the provision and letting of local authority housing in accordance with the concept of the greatest need. I suggest to the House, therefore, that the prudent course is to await the Government's proposals on which we are working as a matter of urgency.

Finally, I would emphasise the danger of looking at this problem in an oversimplified and unduly emotive way. I am fully aware that what many people who are concerned about this Bill have in mind is the real and acute need to raise the lot of people who are among the most deprived in our community.

The Bill, in its present form, will undoubtedly serve the basis for legislation which I am committed to bringing into this House. What I would suggest to the Senators is that some of the problems we have within the Department, together with a most sympathetic analysis and examination of this Independent Senator's Bill and some of the problems we think will arise, could be discussed by the Senators here based on their legislative and local representative experience.

The Bill has 13 sections. Looking through it, I find that because of the way in which we interpret the sections six are either not acceptable or would have a counter-effect to the one that the objective of the Bill would propose, while five are acceptable and two would require amendment, but amendment that would not to any great degree change their substance.

In fairness to Senator Ryan, who has put a lot of work into this Bill, and in fairness to the people who have worked with him both within the Simon Community and in the other voluntary housing associations, it would be constructive and indeed proper for me to give some indication as to the difficulties and reasons for our finding certain sections unacceptable in their present form. As we indicated at the outset, the objective of the legislation and the principle of the Bill are substantially shared by all of us and are certainly shared by me personally.
Section 3 is the one which requires the housing authority to provide accommodation. It reads:

Subject to the provision of this Act, it shall be the duty of a housing authority to provide accommodation of reasonable standard and suitable type for persons in need of such accommodation who are homeless or threatened with homelessness, either through emergency or because of their social conditions and whose means are inadequate to provide such accommodation for themselves.

As we see it, this section imposes a statutory duty, enforceable in law, on housing authorities to provide accommodation of reasonable standard and suitable type for homeless persons or persons threatened with homelessness as defined in section 4 of the Bill. I will come to that later.

If this was enacted in the present way — and these are some of the criticisms we have of the section as it is currently drafted — the health boards would have no function under the Bill in relation to accommodation of homeless persons or persons threatened with homelessness. It appears that this obligation, which exists even in respect of persons who may not in the opinion of the housing authority be capable of holding an independent tenancy because of personal inadequacy, does nor require an authority to house such persons. We may get into a situation where someone, because of his socio-medical condition, is unacceptable to the other tenants in a local authority area, who in fact has been made homeless in the first instance as a result of the request of tenants in the area because of the way in which the person has carried on, through no fault of his own. I can cite specific examples. There was the case of a single woman in her mid-thirties and living on her own, who simply was not well and who on four seperate occasions burned the furniture that had been provided for her by different agencies and did not burn the coal that had been provided for her. She simply disrupted the entire flat complex she lived in. Consistently she left the water running in her flat. She lived on the second floor in a block of flats in Ringsend. The water seeped through the concrete floor in a flat of a neighbour. That small, very closely knit community tried in every way to encourage her to live in a normal way. The local authority could not rehouse her anywhere else because outside that Ringsend area she would not have effectively survived as an individual and no other area in Ringsend would accept her. There were these kinds of pressures. These are some of the implications which, from my point of view, could as a consequence of the definition arise from section 3 in its present form.

“Accommodation of reasonable standard and suitable type,” which is a quote from section 3, is elaborated on by section 12 (2) which deals further with the nature of the accommodation to be provided by the housing authority. The imposition of a statutory duty on local authorities without making available the necessary financial and staffing resources to discharge the duty, would bring the law and local authorities into disrepute. In the prevailing state of public finances — while I share Senator Ryan's commitment to doing what is manifestly right — to quote his own description of the Simon Community as being one which is rooted in practicality, we as legislators must have regard to the state of public finances and realise that there is no prospect of the Exchequer or local authorities being in a position to provide the resources required to give effect to the provisions of the Bill. Senators will recall the debate we had on the local government charges legislation which came through the House in the summer.

The imposition of a duty on housing authorities to give accommodation to one particular category of persons constitutes a major departure from all previous housing legislation with the exception of that for the disabled and the elderly. Regarding the long-established practice of letting houses to those in greatest need, relative needs being determined in accordance with fixed or with certain accepted criteria, under existing legislation housing authorities are obliged to assess housing needs, to draw up building programmes and to make a scheme of letting priorities for the letting of houses provided. In making schemes of letting priorities they are obliged to have regard to certain primary objectives. These are the elimination of unfitness and overcrowding in the provision of housing for persons in need of housing and who cannot afford to house themselves. As I said earlier, it appears that that particular section could be interpreted as being totally in conflict with the main part of section 60 of the Housing Act, 1966. We would, therefore, have the situation where this Bill would be saying one thing and other legislation would be saying another. All of us as legislators would accept that to have that kind of legislation on the Statute Book is unacceptable.

In the definition of homelessness which is the key obviously to this legislation, we have to try to define it in such a way legally that it does not have an overspill effect which I know is not the intention of the promoters of this Bill.
Section 4 of the Bill is quite an elaborate one and reads:
(1) For the purposes of this Act, a person shall be regarded as homeless and in need of accommodation when the housing authority is satisfied that—

(a) he or any person who might be reasonably expected to reside with him; (i) has no accommodation and is vulnerable as a result of old age, mental illness, handicap or physical disability, pregnancy or other special reason and/or (ii) has no fixed abode and/or (iii) is usually resident in common lodging houses, refuges, night shelters or hostels and/or (iv) solely because of having no alternative accommodation is forced to continue to reside in a general or psychiatric hospital, a county home or other such institution; or
(b) he has accommodation but he cannot secure entry to it or it is probable that occupation of it will lead to violence from some other person residing in it; or

(c) his accommodation consists of a movable structure, vehicle or vessel designed or adapted for human habitation and there is no place where he is entitled or permitted both to place it and to reside in it.

(2) For the purposes of this Act, a person is threatened with homelessness if it is likely that within 28 days he will become homeless and in need of accommodation as defined in subsection (1) of this section.

The potential implications of that — again not for the category of 3,000 people to which the Simon Community's report refers, but to other people who would be counted among the 30,000 on the housing list — for the housing authority and for its integration within the context of the body of housing legislation, which in essence is the 1966 Act and some of the subsequent provisions of the 1979 housing miscellaneous legislation, is a necessity to interconnect and tidy up both of the provisions there and the objectives that are being sought in this section.

The terms “homeless” and “threatened with homelessness” are defined in this section. I have read them out but perhaps I could summarise them in nonlegal terms. They are, a person who has no accommodation and who is vulnerable. “Vulnerable” is potentially a very emotive and variable-valued word. What would be interpreted by the courts as “vulnerable” could range very widely up and down from a scale of one to 50, certainly on a scale of one to ten. One would get the kind of anomalies of treatment from one court to another or from one local housing authority to another that would be unacceptable.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Ryan Mr. B. Ryan
Speaker.P: Surely the Minister will accept that to say that somebody has no accommodation is quite unequivocal. It is ‘no accommodation’ and ‘vulnerable’ that the section refers to, not just vulnerable alone.

I accept that if you link the two of them together it could be interpreted in that way but our feeling is that in some cases, given the court structure, that might not be the case. Section 4 provides that a person may be considered homeless if he has accommodation but cannot secure entry to it or if it is probable that occupation will lead to violence from some other person residing in it. This provision is intended to cover the case of battered wives and separated persons, marital breakdown and so on, where it may not be possible or reasonable to expect a person to share accommodation with another. However, it would appear to give a housing right to persons against whom barring orders have been obtained through the courts. On the other hand, it might also discourage a person, say a married woman, from seeking a barring or protection order knowing that she will have to be rehoused if she leaves the home.

MainHeading.P: In that general area of the definition of homelessness I am very concerned about the concept of “threatened homelessness” because whatever about fixing up somebody who has clearly no accommodation, the idea of agreeing on what is threatened homelessness can vary quite substantially. The British Act, for example, has had a very broad definition of homelessness.

Any person who has no accommodation or who is unable to occupy any accommodation he may own or who has a caravan and so on but has no place to park it. However, under the British Act the duty imposed on local authorities extends only to those who have priority need for accommodation. This is the core of a lot of the practical reservations I have, as someone who has been a member of a housing committee and a local housing authority. By all means let us clearly define in legal terms the body responsible for housing the homeless.

The Bill that will become law and which will have a lot to do with this legislation will do a great service if it does that alone. But having done that it is only right and proper that we have got to try to practically incorporate and integrate the homeless person into the system of priority that applies to everybody else. It was a theme of Senator Ryan's speech that he wanted homeless people to have the right to be treated the same as every other citizen. Paradoxically, in this instance, the enactment of your Bill under this section would reverse the kind of prejudice they suffered since the time of Henry VIII. In fact, it would give them a fast track to housing above and beyond the needs of existing applicants and would not have them treated as every other citizen is treated.

In relation to the 3,000 people, there may be a very pressing argument for some degree of affirmative action in that area. That is for another day's argument but the effect of this section of the Bill would have that outcome. Senator Ryan quoted the justification for enacting this legislation on the basis that it will not open a floodgate of demand for housing because the British experience did not have that effect. But the British legislation had written into it this integration with the general body of housing legislation, the concept of priority need. We can legislate for the homeless and legislate for its definition and not create an anomalous situation in law that would produce the reverse of the desire to have them treated equally with every other citizen for the first time.

Sections 3, 4, and 5 really contain the meat of this Bill. I should like very briefly to refer to the inquiries to be made by local authorities. As we read it, the implication, among other things, would be that the local authority would be obliged, during the course of their inquiries to determine if the applicant for accommodation is homeless or not or even threatened with homelessness to provide temporary accommodation. They are also obliged to investigate the needs of all homeless persons and to regard them as homeless, irrespective of whether they have made application, and thus entitle them to be housed. The administrative implications of trying to do that with many people who, by virtue of their homelessness, have many other problems which have come as a result of their being homeless, are enormous. We would need to limit the degree to which we are imposing duties on local housing authorities. I can recall quite clearly the debate which took place in the summer of this year in relation to local government charges. Indeed, I can recall in particular the eloquent prophecies of the Leas-Chathaoirleach in relation to the outbursts of rage that would come from local authorities with regard to giving them more tasks and obligations in a situation of limited resources. I can just imagine your rhetorical eloquence on the subsection in this Bill if the honest burgesses of Clare County Council were required to implement in this way some of the provisions.

Speaker.P: We have no homeless in Clare.

It is that kind of administrative eloquence I have frequently admired about the people of Clare. There are, however, those difficulties. Section 6 has similar problems but they are capable of being resolved.

I want to conclude the Second Stage contribution on behalf of the Government by repeating what I said at the outset, that is, that there is a very clear need to legislate. It is quite obvious now that the urgency of the introduction of legislation has been made a reality by the action that has been taken by Senator Ryan — to whom I pay public tribute in this regard — and by the voluntary associations and housing organisations that have provided him with the research and details that were set out in his speech. So far as I am concerned, we will move as fast as possible, and it is up to this House to ensure that the speed at which we move is maintained, to introduce legislation that will do the things which I and many people in this House want: to clearly define who is responsible for the homeless, to clearly define what constitutes being homeless, and also clearly define, if we can, the border line between being homeless and being made homeless or being threatened with homelessness. There is a very real problem in relation to people who are being made homeless through no fault of their own under the existing rents legislation. We have now the body of work which has been done by the housing associations and which has been put so eloquently on the record of this House today.

MainHeading.P: I have said all I need to say in relation to this legislation. I repeat formally that the commitment is there and that it will be acted upon. I wish to repeat publicly and I hope to the wider public by way of the media, that I have been somewhat overjoyed by the degree of response from the religious orders, in the way in which they have responded so enthusiastically to the extraordinary degrees of mobilisation that Senator Ryan has evidenced here today. The local authorities can, as a result of the telex, formally write to the various religious orders whose names are registered in the text of the Seanad Official Debate and inquire from them what kind of land could be made available at existing use prices. There is no question of expropriation or donations being required or demanded.

Their commitment to deal with this problem is very welcome. Their enormous land resources are an intrinsic component of any solution and it is becoming increasingly a critical component in view of the scarce resources that this Administration have been left to run the country with. No doubt Senators, from their unique knowledge of their own local authorities, will be able to identify other religious orders who were not mobilised in time by Senator Ryan but who would equally share the enthusiasm of the ones associated with this telex and who may reside in the more isolated parts of Ireland. Homelessness is not uniquely an urban problem so perhaps those other orders could contribute in these difficult times in making resources available at a reasonable price based on existing use and not the prospective speculative value that otherwise might be put on land.
For those reasons and others which I have already outlined I compliment the Senator for moving this legislation and for affording the House the opportunity of debating it.

Speaker.P: I am giving the Senator the opportunity of speaking first on the resumption of this debate. That is all I can do.

MainHeading.RHead: and Judicial Offices (Amendment) Bill, 1983: Second Stage
MainHeading.Title: Oireachtas (Allowances to Members) and Ministerial, Parliamentary and Judicial Offices (Amendment) Bill, 1983: Second Stage.
MainHeading.P: Question proposed: “That the Bill be now read a Second Time”.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Boland) John Boland
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Boland)
Speaker.P: I am sure that Senators are, by now, quite well aware of the general provisions of this Bill.

MainHeading.P: Any adjustment in the remuneration of parliamentarians inevitably gives rise to a great deal of critical comment, much of which, as we have seen over the past week, can be confused and misleading.

The simple fact is that Senators, Dáil Deputies, parliamentary office holders and members of the Judiciary have not received any increase in their remuneration for almost two and a half years — since June 1981. This position has arisen notwithstanding that the Review Body on Higher Remuneration in the Public Sector in their report of 30 October 1979 clearly indicated that the levels of remuneration which they recommended, and which the Government at the time accepted, should in the future attract all standard national agreements or other general round increases.

The provisions of the 1981 Public Service Pay Agreement, as amended, which provided for three phased increases of 2 per cent, 6 per cent and 5 per cent have been applied to all the groups dealt with by the review body with the exception only of parliamentarians and the Judiciary.
Since 1 September last, the first phase of the 1983 public service pay agreement has also been payable in the public service involving a further increase of 4.75 per cent.

It is, I believe, unfair and undesirable that parliamentarians or the Judiciary should, for no good reason, be excluded from the benefit of national or Public Service pay agreements which apply to all other categories of public servants. Failure to implement their provisions can only give rise to greater problems in the future when steps have to be taken to correct the neglect of past years. The Bill, therefore, provides that the increases under the 1981 Public Service pay agreement — 2 per cent, 6 per cent and 5 per cent — and the first phase of the 1983 public service pay agreement, 4.75 per cent, will be applied as from 1 September 1983, but without retrospection, to parliamentarians and to the annual sums payable to leaders of certain parties in Dáil Éireann. The full provisions as from the due dates, that is with retrospection, will be implemented in respect of the Judiciary. The Bill also provides that in the future general pay rounds applied to the Civil Service will also automatically apply to Oireachtas Members and to the Judiciary with effect from the appropriate dates. In this way the recommendation of the review body will, in the future, be adhered to.

I do not think that there is any good reason for depriving the Judiciary of the retrospective elements of these increases and for thus treating them less favourably than the rest of the public service. Accordingly, the Bill provides that the increases under the 1981 Public Service Pay Agreement and the first phase of the 1983 agreement will be applied in their case with retrospection to the due dates, that is, 2 per cent from 1 December 1981, 6 per cent from 1 March 1982, 5 per cent from 1 October 1982, together with 4.75 per cent from 1 September 1983.

In the case of the parliamentarians, however, the Government have decided that the 1981 agreement increases will apply from 1 September 1983 and without retrospection. As a result of this, TDs who served since the 1981 agreement came into effect will be at a permanent loss of £2,320 approximately which is the amount by which their remuneration fell short during the period up to 31 August 1983 and Senators will be at a corresponding loss of £1,450. A Senator currently in receipt of £7,619 per annum since June 1981 — if retrospection had been allowed — would have moved on 1 December 1981 to £7,828, on 1 March 1982 to £8,298 and on 1 January 1983 to £8,713 — this last phase to have actually been paid in January of this year, rather than October 1982, in accordance with the amendments to the 1981 agreement.

In the light of the prevailing economic climate I believe that Members of the Seanad will appreciate the reasons which compelled the Government to decide against payment of retrospection for parliamentarians.

These increases merely apply to parliamentarians, without the benefit of retrospection, a number of public service pay agreement phases which have applied from the due dates to public servants generally. Adjustments of this order have also been granted in the private sector. The 19 per cent increase so widely commented on in recent days is no more than the aggregate of these phases which have been enjoyed for up to two years by all other groups but which have been withheld until now from parliamentarians.

The opportunity is being taken in the legislation to amend the manner in which the terms of general round increases — such as those under the public service pay agreements — are applied to Members of the Oireachtas and the Judiciary in the future. Up to now a cumbersome procedure has resulted in a situation where many months could — and often did — elapse between the decision to implement a pay round and its actual payment. Firstly, there is required a Government decision, followed by the making of a Statutory Order which, in turn, must be laid before the Dáil for 21 sitting days before taking effect. Should a recess intervene, or if the decision to initiate the procedure takes place during a recess, the process is even longer. It will be obvious, therefore, that without delay on the part of Government, a considerable time may elapse before an ordinary phase, payable to all others, is actually paid to the Members of the Legislature.

In the past this process has resulted in a situation where a single increase has been reported or commented upon on a number of different occasions, giving the impression that there had, in fact, been a series of increases actually paid during the period. In the future, therefore, and commencing with the enacting of this legislation and the current public service pay agreement, increases applying generally to the Civil Service will be applied automatically to Members of the Oireachtas, to the annual sums payable to certain party leaders, and to the Judiciary, with effect from the due date in each case.

In relation to any other changes in parliamentary remuneration, arising, for example, as a result of a review body inquiry, provision is being made so that, in future, an order having immediate effect could be made either increasing or decreasing such remuneration and such an order would be capable of being annulled by resolution of the Dáil within 21 sitting days but without prejudice to anything already done thereunder.
In the case of the Judiciary, orders increasing remuneration will simply be presented to both Houses but would not, for constitutional reasons, be capable of annulment.

When a Seanad general election is called, as the House is probably aware, Senators continue to be paid their allowance until the day before polling day. Accordingly, a Senator who is re-elected continues to receive payment of the allowance without a break. A Dáil Deputy, however, ceases to qualify for allowance as from the date of dissolution of the Dáil — recent dissolutions have lasted for approximately three weeks — and qualification for resumption of payment does not occur until, and unless, the Deputy is re-elected to the subsequent Dáil. This has caused a serious loss of income to Deputies in recent years because of the holding of three general elections in a relatively short period of time.

The Review Body on Higher Remuneration in the Public Sector commented on this matter at paragraph 12.18 of the October 1979 report and said they felt that consideration should be given to the question of continuing payment of TDs' allowances up to the date before polling day for the new Dáil. The Government have decided that a sum equivalent to one-eighteenth of annual allowance shall be payable to a Deputy on dissolution of a Dáil. Arrangements will also be made to include the period of dissolution as reckonable for pension purposes.

Certain other changes, basically of a minor nature, are being brought into effect under the Bill. These include provision to allow changes to be made to the Members' pension scheme by ministerial amending scheme, provision that the posts of Cathaoirleach and Leas-Chathaoirleach of the Seanad be made pensionable, provision for amending the conditions for regarding the post of Attorney-General as pensionable and provision for removal of an anomaly in the pension terms of certain former Parliamentary Secretaries, which unintentionally resulted from the pension provisions for Ministers of State in the Oireachtas (Allowances to Members) and Ministerial, Parliamentary and Judicial Offices (Amendment) Act, 1977. I will be happy to explain these changes more fully on Committee Stage, where necessary.

It is my intention to introduce, by way of amending scheme under the new procedure, an optional situation whereby a defeated or retiring Member of the Oireachtas who has served the requisite eight qualifying years may decide to draw pension on the basis of one-fortieth for each year of service as at present, or, alternatively, to choose a lump sum, calculated actuarially, together with reduced pension payments based on three-one hundred and sixtieths for each year of service.

I also intend modifying the pension scheme to allow those with short service, who are not qualified for pension, to have their own pension contributions refunded to them as happens in most other pension schemes. This matter was referred to by the review body at paragraph 12.13 of their 1979 Report.

The review body, in dealing with superannuation matters, stated at paragraph 12.20 that they were taking the 6 per cent contribution payable by Members into account in considering the appropriate level of allowance and went on to say that if changes were to be made in relation to the refund of contributions where Members fail to qualify for pensions, severance grants for Deputies and the continuance of TDs' allowances beyond the date of dissolution of a Dail, these would have to be part of an overall package and improvements in benefits on these lines would require modifications elsewhere in existing arrangements.

As already stated, two of these matters are being dealt with, and it is my intention that these changes, and Members' conditions generally, will be considered by the review body when next a general review similar to that reported on in 1979 takes place. In relation to the question of severance grants the Government have decided against the introduction of such payments.

While they do not form part of the specific provisions of this Bill, nevertheless I think I should tell the House that it is also the intention of the Government, in conjunction with the passing of the Bill, to update Members' travelling, overnight and day allowances. These rates have not been increased since January 1980 and have clearly fallen out of line. For the future, Members who qualify will be paid the same mileage rates as are, for the time being, allowed to civil servants.

The present overnight allowance of £17.50 for those Members who are obliged to stay in Dublin while the Houses are in session is to be revised to £27.50. This applies where the Member resides more than 20 miles from the GPO and stays overnight in Dublin. The day allowance, payable to those Members who reside within ten miles of the House, is increasing from £10 to £16. Mileage allowance is not, may I remind the House, payable to these Members.

It should be pointed out that this was the level of increase which was deemed to be appropriate nearly a year ago. It is intended that, in the future, these figures will be adjusted by reference to Civil Service mileage and subsistence rates.

While on the subject of expenses, I would like to refer to what I consider to have been less than responsible coverage of this aspect in certain sections of the media. These have suggested that payments for expenses in some way constitute additional remuneration. Nothing could be further from the truth. The rates payable to Members of the Oireachtas are designed to recoup out-of-pocket expenses. It would surely be unreasonable to suggest that Members could carry out their duties as public representatives, such as travelling to Dublin for meetings of the Oireachtas, without incurring out-of-pocket expenses on travelling and accommodation. The overnight allowance payable is far from generous when compared to similar rates paid to many others, in both the public and private sectors, whose duties involve them in being away from home for protracted periods.

All that the main provisions of the Bill set out to do is to restore Members and the Judiciary to the level which the review body recommended they should be at, and maintained at, through application of wage agreements. This is being done by granting the terms of the 1981 Public Service pay agreement and the first phase of the 1983 agreement. In the case of parliamentarians the adjustment will take effect only from September last. This restores Members' remuneration to the level recommended by the review body but without retrospection. In the case of Seanad membership this results in a permanent loss of some £1,450 in retrospection vis-à-vis comparable Public Service income earners.

As I stated in Dáil Éireann there is an obligation upon those of us entrusted with the operation of a democracy to ensure that the democratic system is able to work. If we should see fit to shirk from providing for what we know is a fair, just and reasonable payment to any Member doing his or her job, and to single out parliamentarians alone as the group who should not be allowed increases applicable to the rest of society, and whose application to parliamentarians has been recommended by an independent review body, then we are doing both Parliament and democracy itself a disservice. I commend the Bill to the House.

Speaker.P: I must commend the Minister on having come to the House with a Bill which is, to a number of people, the first one which is unpopular. It is extremely unpopular amongst the members of the public. There has been much comment on it, a lot of which has not been fully researched or thought out. Perhaps this is the first time that an unpopular public Bill has been recommended to the House.

MainHeading.P: I shall not go into what has been said in the other House or into what has been said in the media. But I will say that it is a very necessary Bill. I would suggest it was more necessary for the Members of this House than for those of the other House. There have been comments about the operations of this House or indeed the necessity for this House. We are a House of the Oireachtas. We play a very important part in the organisation of legislation. I would not hesitate to say that the level of debate on all aspects of legislation in this House has been equal to, if not better than, that in the other House. To many people we might seem to be irrelevant and it might appear as if we should be abolished. But I do not feel that this should be a House into which people are propelled, in their wheelchairs with a remedial teacher on one side, a blood bag on the other, being wheeled in to convalesce having been either defeated in the Dáil or not been selected for election to that House.

This House is very relevant. I was extremely upset by the remark of a trade unionist whom I would consider to be as well paid as any Member of this House, whether he be fulltime or part time, when he said the Seanad should be abolished, that we had dipped our hands into the public till to the tune of 19 per cent, plus expenses, that it was frightening. And, as the final insult, this trade union official said that the political convalescent home known as the Senate should be closed down, that the majority of its occupants are people who got the thumbs down from the electorate. He expressed amazement that the figure of £9,000 per annum could be paid as disappointment money. This was said by the General Secretary of the National Busworkers' Union at a conference in Ballina, County Mayo, last week. I presume that that trade union official was paid expenses to go to Ballina, County Mayo.

Speaker.P: I will not have a word said about Ballina.

Ballina would be a beautiful place to go to and I would suggest that the said trade unionist had an enjoyable weekend there at the expense of the National Busworkers' Union. There is absolutely no doubt that he claimed his expenses. I suggest that his salary as General Secretary of the National Busworkers' Union is at least double that being paid to Members of this House.

I shall not advance any major case for the increase in the allowances to Senators but I can say that we are, in the main, part-time politicians. I make no bones about the fact that as part-time politicians every day that we come to this House costs us money. It has cost anybody who is in business an enormous amount of money. That is not only because we are unable, in our own businesses, to do the job as we were doing it before becoming Members but equally we have lost the confidence of our bankers, of the people who had been supporting us financially. Anybody who has gone on the Seanad trail will know how much it costs. Anybody who would maintain that £9,000 per annum — which is the new rate — would in any way compensate us is living in cloud-cuckoo land. I make no bones about the fact that we are part-time politicians. I do not think we are over-paid as part-time politicians. One might ask what is a part-time politician? A part-time politician — looking around on this side of the House, and I see people on the far side of the House also — is somebody who neglects his business, who goes to meetings seven nights a week, somebody who never sees his home and who has financial problems created because of his part-time obligation to the Oireachtas.

MainHeading.P: The adjustment being made is extremely necessary. I am not going to say that there are not people around the country who would have a justifiable case in maintaining that we should not get it because their position is worse. I do not think that should be the argument. The case was made again that, unless we receive reasonable remuneration, the Houses of the Oireachtas will become a rich man's club. I am afraid the time has come — because of the cost involved — that it will be a rich man's club, or it will be a club for people who are retired or, for those people supported by outside interests. The day that this House becomes one supported by outside interests — in the same way as has happened in the United States and in other countries — will be the day democracy ceases to function here. There is the situation obtaining in a lot of democracies at present in which parliamentarians are not paid sufficient to do the job they are supposed to do. What has happened in these democracies? Special-interest money is being poured behind these politicians. And unless such politicians take the line of such special interests they will not be re-elected to the United States Congress or Senate. At present in the United Kingdom their Members of Parliament are allowed to take extra money from special interest groups as long as they declare that special interest. Therefore, if an oil company approaches an MP in the United Kingdom and says: we will pay you an extra £5,000 a year as long as you support us in legislation, that is all right as long as he declares that interest. I would not like to see the day that we, in this Legislature, would have to depend on outside monies to remain here. A step has been taken in the direction of ensuring that we operate as an independent Oireachtas, independent in the sense that we will be enabled to remain in office, without outside support.

I shall not delay the House any longer. I was somewhat disappointed the debate did not commence until 8 o'clock. I presume it will continue until such time as each Stage is passed irrespective of the time and that anybody who has anything to say on any Stage will be so allowed.
